Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding and Reducing Student Resistance as a Barrier to Faculty Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This WIDER research project focuses on understanding student resistance as a barrier to STEM faculty adoption of evidence-based teaching methods in the context of introductory engineering courses at University of Michigan, Virginia Tech, North Carolina A & T, and Bucknell University. The project is investigating three related research questions, including: 1) What factors (including faculty strategies, student experience, institution and course type, and student and faculty characteristics) influence student resistance to nontraditional teaching methods? 2) To what extent does expectancy violation theory explain student resistance to nontraditional teaching methods? and 3) What specific, evidence-based strategies (and in what contexts) can faculty employ to significantly reduce student resistance? To address these questions, the project team is employing rigorous instrument development procedures to design surveys to measure student resistance and expectancy violation, and conducting in-depth studies at a range of institutions, combining qualitative methods with quantitative surveys to identify additional factors related to student resistance. The final phase of the project includes a full-scale study of 20 introductory engineering courses. Expected products include evidence-based strategies faculty can use to reduce student resistance, student surveys that faculty can use to monitor their own progress in reducing student resistance, and a classroom observation protocol focusing on student resistance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding and reducing student resistance as a barrier to faculty change.

There have been calls to improve engineering education instruction in undergraduate classrooms across the nation. Research has shown that improved teaching methods such as active learning help with engineering and STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) students’ retention, learning gains, engagement, motivation, and satisfaction. However, many undergraduate engineering classrooms remain traditional and lecture-based, and some STEM faculty members have anxiety about incorporating other teaching methods in their classrooms. Previous research has shown that engineering instructors anticipate students not liking different types of teaching methods and showing resistance. This research project explored how and if students resisted nontraditional teaching methods such as active learning and identified strategies for instructors to reduce student resistance. 

We created the Student Response to Instructional Practices (StRIP) survey to carefully examine how students responded and resisted different teaching methods in their classrooms. The survey was constructed to be reliable and valid with multiple rounds of survey testing, pilot classrooms, focus groups, and observations. The final survey was sent out to 18 different undergraduate engineering classrooms throughout the United States. 

Around 1000 students were surveyed, and we found many of the students responded positively to active learning in their classrooms. Engineering instructors should find comfort in knowing that the many students do enjoy active learning and nontraditional teaching methods in their classrooms. Cases of student resistance were minimal, and when we interviewed instructors about student resistance, most instructors were only able to give a few examples of when students resisted. Many students on average did not appear to resist active learning. 

We proceeded to understand what predicted a students’ response to active learning. We found that students’ responses were explained more by the perceived usage of instructor strategies than by other factors. It seemed that students responded well to how instructors implemented active learning in the classrooms. 

Instructors should be mindful of two types of instructor strategies: explanation and facilitation. Explanation strategies make expectations for the in-class activity or the nontraditional teaching method clear. Facilitation strategies occur after the in-class activity has started, and facilitation strategies guide and help students throughout the in-class activity. Our list of empirically validated instructor strategies includes:

*Explanation

 o Clearly explained the purpose of the activities. 

 o Discussed how the activities related to my learning.

 o Clearly explained what I was expected to do for the activities. 

*Facilitation

 o Encouraged students to engage with the activities through his/her demeanor.

 o Invited students to ask questions about the activities.

 o Walked around the room to assist me or my group with the activities, if needed. 

o Confronted students who were not participating in the activities.

o Solicited my feedback or that of other students about the activities.

In sum, engineering instructors in undergraduate classrooms throughout the nation should be relieved to know that many students do not resist nontraditional teaching methods and active learning. This finding should help more instructors adopt proven research-based instructional strategies and teaching methods in their classrooms. We have also explored and verified practical and useful instructor strategies to consider when implementing nontraditional teaching methods and active learning in the classroom. Instructors should benefit knowing that these strategies can help ease them into using proven research based teaching methods. The nation will benefit from having more STEM and engineering students succeed in their classrooms.
